urn:contentItem:5M8X-2V41-JD3N-524N-00000-00The power of movies2016-11-30T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:38:12ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 27The power of moviesMIRANDA MURPHY - MURPHY'S LORE

We give our childhood film education a red-hot go

We've been trying to wean our kids off animated movie schlock like Barbie And The Three Musketeers and Scooby Doo Solves The Kennedy Assassination.

It's not easy; they think that any piece of live-action film is basically the news and doubly boring.

But still we persist. And so we drew up a list of our favourite Gen Xer kids' movies that we hoped they would love too.

When we showed our kids ET, we were prepared with tissues. They came in handy for my husband and me, who sobbed like toddlers. The kids, however, were strangely unmoved. Were our offspring sociopaths? Why weren't they doubled over with tears at the saddest, loveliest movie ever made?

Turns out they considered ET to be just a big rubber puppet. CGI animation has got that good that anything prior just looks lame.

We've given our childhood movie education a red-hot go, though. They loved Honey, I Shrunk The Kids, ThePrincess Bride, and the Star Wars movies - although when a major character got killed off our seven-year-old cried "Dad! You've taken me to the wrong movie!" That's the power of films, especially for kids.

Good triumphs over evil, orphans defeat the system, horrid comeuppances are delivered to wrongdoers.

Of course, you've got to be wary of the dark themes. Parental guidance is recommended, so when my children asked to watch Bambi, I was wary. I briefed them on the traumatically tragic death of Bambi's mum.

"How does she die?" asked one. "Um, I can't remember," I replied. "Maybe in the forest fire." After a bit, one of the kids came bursting in, triumphantly exclaiming: "Mum! You were wrong! Bambi's mum didn't get caught in the fire - she was killed by hunters!"Miranda Murphy is a mother of three and a journalist at The Australian

urn:contentItem:5R20-XXX1-F0J6-J4T9-00000-00Fighting fire from the air: Bendigo helicopters ready for season2017-11-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:38:12ZLexisNexisNEWSFighting fire from the air: Bendigo helicopters ready for seasonAshley Fritsch

It's an unmistakable sound when the mercury's high and the conditions are dry - the thundering of a water-bombing helicopter flying overhead.

Central Victoria's team of firefighting helicopters arrived in Bendigo on Wednesday, ready to take on grass and bushfires within a 70km radius from the airport.

The yellow and blue helicopter responsible for dumping water from the sky is the Helitak 335, which works in conjunction with the Firebird 305, used to coordinate the aerial attack.

Forest Fire Management Victoria fire and emergency preparedness regional manager Carsten Nannestad said the pair was an important weapon for the bushfire season.

"They are very important and they work really well with our ground crews," he said.

"It's that combination of air support and ground crews that put the fire out."

The Helitak carries just under 3000 litres of water and can fill its belly tank in 35 seconds.

"It's a very quick machine and this is what makes it really well suited for our area here," Mr Nannestad said.

"We've got a lot of small farm dams that can be used as water sources and it generally doesn't have to go far to find water in the landscape to put the fire out."

It is the fifth year the firefighting duo has been stationed at Bendigo for the fire season, responding to call outs across central Victoria.

On days above low to moderate fire danger, the choppers are dispatched to any grass or bushfire in their area.

"It's very important that we get the aircraft airborne as quickly as possible so as soon as somebody detects a fire and makes a triple-0 call, we get a page," Mr Nannestad said.

"Statistically, last year they were airborne within 11 minutes of getting the page and they were over the fire within 28 minutes of getting the page."

The team received its first two call outs within a day of arriving, with a bushfire at Sutton Grange and a grass fire at Tarrengower on Thursday.

Country Fire Authority Loddon Mallee regional commander Scott Purdy said both were started by common things like slashing grass and lawn mowers, and urged the community to review what they were doing.

"Things are drying out now and those same activities are starting fires," he said.

"The risk of fire is real, it is occurring. We are seeing that it is going to get worse so people need to have finalised all their preparatory works and be mindful restrictions are in."

urn:contentItem:4P85-18G0-TXN5-R1PY-00000-00Duo proves money isn't everything1998-01-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:38:12ZLexisNexisSPORTPg. 43Duo proves money isn't everythingRACINGMAX PRESNELL

Two battlers stole the limelight at Randwick yesterday, a day after hopeful buyers with $1 million to splurge didn't even get into the bidding for Octagonal's kid brother at New Zealand's National Yearling Sale.

Forest Fire, out of an unraced dam, covered far more ground in the Alexander Mackellar Handicap than any other runner but proved much too good for Sound, backed from 16-1 to 8-1.

His performance was certainly superior to some of the classic types carrying the polish of the best trainers and navigation of the top jockeys.

Sound, prepared by leading trainer John Hawkes and ridden by Larry Cassidy, carried the cerise silks of Australia's biggest owners, Jack and Bob Ingham.

The Inghams, of course, raced the mighty Octagonal. It was his feats and the gilt-edged off-spring of his dam, Eight Carat, that saw the record price paid in New Zealand on Tuesday.

Sound, too, is New Zealand-bred, being by Grosvenor, another Sir Tristram stallion, out of Sonolia, which won eight races.

But yesterday Sound ended up well in the wake of Forest Fire, a 15-1 chance, which skirted high, wide and handsome for apprentice Kelly Dunn and had a length-and-three-quarters to spare at the finish.

Forest Fire has now won four from nine races and trainer Geoff Maynes regards the Forest Glow three-year-old as a "family horse".

"I purchased his grand dam Basia in New Zealand and also his dam [Greygum Lady] but she hurt a leg and never got to the barrier," Maynes said.

The trainer wasn't concerned about Forest Fire being wide because he has a tendency to "run away from other horses".

"I told Kelly the ground was probably better out there, too," he said.

Perhaps so but no other runner on the program went so wide and ended with such a convincing result.

Forest Fire also left Scud - which eased from 5-2 to 11-2 - in his wake. Ridden by Shane Dye, Scud, a half brother to Might And Power, could finish only fifth but there is a pay day coming up shortly for him.

Dye, tipped to get the prize mount on outstanding staying three-year-old Tie The Knot in coming autumn feature events, was later successful on 13-4 favourite Making Fey in the James White Handicap.

Making Fey's trainer, Gai Waterhouse, was reported by AAP as the underbidder for Tuesday's record-priced Zabeel-Eight Carat yearling.

Making Fey, also by Zabeel, cost only "around $35,000", according to Waterhouse stable manager Leslie Dennett.

Waterhouse had a double with In House, the 11-4 favourite, in the Richard Jones Handicap and he, too, has an Octagonal connection through his dam, Cotehele House. Cotehele House's dam is Eight Carat.

urn:contentItem:5R20-XXX1-F0J6-J4S5-00000-00Fighting fire from the air: Bendigo helicopters ready for season2017-11-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:38:12ZLexisNexisFighting fire from the air: Bendigo helicopters ready for seasonAshley Fritsch

It's an unmistakable sound when the mercury's high and the conditions are dry - the thundering of a water-bombing helicopter flying overhead.

Central Victoria's team of firefighting helicopters arrived in Bendigo on Wednesday, ready to take on grass and bushfires within a 70km radius from the airport.

The yellow and blue helicopter responsible for dumping water from the sky is the Helitak 335, which works in conjunction with the Firebird 305, used to coordinate the aerial attack.

Forest Fire Management Victoria fire and emergency preparedness regional manager Carsten Nannestad said the pair was an important weapon for the bushfire season.

"They are very important and they work really well with our ground crews," he said.

"It's that combination of air support and ground crews that put the fire out."

The Helitak carries just under 3000 litres of water and can fill its belly tank in 35 seconds.

"It's a very quick machine and this is what makes it really well suited for our area here," Mr Nannestad said.

"We've got a lot of small farm dams that can be used as water sources and it generally doesn't have to go far to find water in the landscape to put the fire out."

It is the fifth year the firefighting duo has been stationed at Bendigo for the fire season, responding to call outs across central Victoria.

On days above low to moderate fire danger, the choppers are dispatched to any grass or bushfire in their area.

"It's very important that we get the aircraft airborne as quickly as possible so as soon as somebody detects a fire and makes a triple-0 call, we get a page," Mr Nannestad said.

"Statistically, last year they were airborne within 11 minutes of getting the page and they were over the fire within 28 minutes of getting the page."

The team received its first two call outs within a day of arriving, with a bushfire at Sutton Grange and a grass fire at Tarrengower on Thursday.

Country Fire Authority Loddon Mallee regional commander Scott Purdy said both were started by common things like slashing grass and lawn mowers, and urged the community to review what they were doing.

"Things are drying out now and those same activities are starting fires," he said.

"The risk of fire is real, it is occurring. We are seeing that it is going to get worse so people need to have finalised all their preparatory works and be mindful restrictions are in."

urn:contentItem:5R26-76C1-F0JP-W1G7-00000-00Street Watch2017-11-28T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:38:12ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 7Street Watch

1 YARRA RANGES Yarra Ranges police have arrested a Croydon man after a spate of thefts from pet supply shops and veterinarians. Yarra Ranges crime investigation unit detective acting Sergeant Mark Hodgson said there had been burglaries across the Yarra Ranges and the south eastern suburbs this year. Acting Sgt Hodgson said a 41-year-old man was arrested and charged with burglary, theft, drugs, weapons, and counterfeit currency offences. He will face the Ringwood Magistrates' Court later this month.

2 MOOROOLBARK More than 20 items of stolen mail and identity documents were seized when police raided a Mooroolbark house. Officers from the Croydon divisional tasking unit searched a Mooroolbark house and found 24 pieces of mail and identity documents, plus ice, on November 1. Detective Acting Senior Sergeant Clayton Bickerton said police arrested and charged a 37-year-old Mooroolbark woman with theft and other offences. She was remanded to face the Ringwood Magistrates' Court on a later date.

3 GEMBROOK Firefighters battled a bushfire in Bunyip State Park in Gembrook last week. Waterbombing aircraft, Forest Fire Management Victoria crews, and CFA firefighters from Gembrook, Tynong, Bunyip and Toomuc, fought the 23ha blaze. An advice warning was issued but there was no threat to communities. Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning spokesman Nick Talbot said last week the cause was not known.

4 YARRA RANGES An increase in burglaries and car theft has police warning residents to vigilant. Croydon divisional tasking unit detective Acting Senior Sergeant Clayton Bickerton said there had been a series of cars stolen and houses burgled in Upwey and Tecoma. "We stress to vehicle and homeowners to be vigilant and remove items from the car and be more security conscious," Acting Sen-Sgt Bickerton said.

5 YARRA RANGES Speeding is the major cause of crashes on Australian roads, a nationwide police operation has revealed. More than 6500 drivers were caught speeding during the 24-hour Operation Safe Speeds on Thursday, November 16. Victoria Police road policing command Assistant Commissioner Doug Fryer said the results were concerning considering speed was one of the main contributing factors in collisions on Australian roads. "It's really disappointing to think that nationally, 275 motorists were detected over the limit every hour," AC Fryer said. "Even low-level speeding of 5km/h or 10km/h over the limit doubles the chance of a collision," Assistant Commissioner Fryer said. The highest speed detected was 185km/h in a 100km zone.

urn:contentItem:5VK5-CH41-JD34-V3DK-00000-00Bunyip fire attracts criticism2019-03-07T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:38:12ZLexisNexisBunyip fire attracts criticismPeter Kostos

Criticism of fire-fighting operations and the management of state and national parks has been levelled at authorities as a result of the Bunyip State Park fire.

The fire at Bunyip is one of many in Gippsland and up in the High Country that is still burning.

Labertouche North property owner Mark McGuffie, whose property abounds the Bunyip State Park, was one landholder critical of a "lack of management" of the park.

Mr McGuffie suffered property loss in the Black Saturday fires in February 2009 and had been critical of park management then.

He said nothing had changed since that time.

"I have 200 hectares of pasture, and a boundary with the State Park, kilometres in length," he said.

"In the 25 years I have owned the farm, the fire access track that runs the full length of my boundary has been blocked by fallen trees and purposefully-dug channels to stop vehicular access."

Mr McGuffie said he had the highest regard for the Country Fire Authority (CFA) volunteers, but not its hierarchy.

"There were six fire trucks just 2.5 kilometres away at a neighbour's property, but they were instructed not to attend my place," he said.

CFA chief officer Steve Warrington defended the authority and its volunteers.

"I make no apology for the strategic decisions that we make on the overall picture, particularly in relation to the safety of people - that includes community members, houses and firefighters," Mr Warrington said.

"We will make decisions not to send trucks into certain areas on the grounds of safety; trees can fall any time after a fire front has passed and we've already had one truck damaged.

"We will make decisions on asset protection, which can mean we've instructed crews to attack a fire from a certain position in more suitable conditions.

"Fire intensity can mean we hold water to attack in a more effective manner in a way that is safer for our crews."

Mr McGuffie said the only thing that saved his property on Sunday was a wind change and the Bunyip River.

He was angry with what he said was the continual ignorance of the state government and authorities.

But the Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning (DELWP) said more than 57 planned burns covering 2110 hectares had been conducted across the State in 2018-19.

DELWP senior media advisor Michael Pollock said mechanical treatments had also accounted for more than 5241 hectares of treatments for a total area treated of more than 7351ha.

Minister for Energy, Environment and Climate Change Lily D'Ambrosio said planned burns were a critical part of Victoria's bushfire management program, however were not something they relied on entirely.

"Public safety has to be our number one priority and we do not want to see a repeat of the Lancefield planned burn in 2015 where a badly planned burn in poor conditions led to disaster," Ms D'Ambrosio said.

"Where weather conditions make planned burning too dangerous, other fire mitigation strategies are used, such as fuel break slashing, track/culvert maintenance and removing obstacles and hazardous trees."

After advice from the Inspector General Emergency Management, Forest Fire Management Vic used a risk-reduction target to focus fuel management strategies on areas that would have the greatest impact.

A Government spokesperson said FFMVIC implemented a number of bushfire prevention measures in Bunyip State Park over the past 10 years, including planned burns in 2008, 2012 and 2016.

Recent opportunities for scheduled planned burns in the Bunyip area had been limited due to ongoing dry conditions.

Works carried out included about 45km of fuel break slashed in Bunyip State Park, including some earlier this year, and improvements to around 5km of dangerous roads through mulching vegetation and removed obstacles and hazardous trees.

The works also improved about 24km of tracks and two strategic fire access roads.

urn:contentItem:5VKB-1KR1-JD34-V494-00000-00Thomson Dam needs wise heads after fire2019-03-08T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:38:12ZLexisNexisOPINIONLettersPg. 18Thomson Dam needs wise heads after fireFORESTS AND LOGGING

Ross Gittins hits the nail on the head ("Policy doesn't hold water", Comment, 6/3). There is something more to be added to his concern, especially for Melbourne and Gippsland.

The huge forest fire now "under control" along the western side of our Thomson Dam has not attracted much media because no houses have been dramatically lost.

However, it has serious ramifications for our water supply, and for timber resources. These can be aggravated by our management of the area over the coming year, while the soil lacks vegetation to protect and to hold it together when rain does arrive.

Bushfires lead to demands for "salvage" logging. The machinery churns the topsoil, making it much more erodible, adding far more dirt to the dam with every rainfall. It destroys the natural layering of the seedbed upon which our forests depend for sustainable recovery.

We need to protect this area particularly carefully to ensure that short-term opportunism does not even further destroy its critical long-term forest and catchment values.

John Poppins, Yarragon South

In government, it's the blind leading the weak

How is it that the environmental and economic values of native forests are obvious to everyone except the state government (Comment, 6/3)?

The best parts of Strathbogie's native forest are again scheduled for logging, sanctioned by the weak Environment Department. Under its watch we are seeing the destruction of invaluable services; water security, carbon capture, biodiversity, pollination, tourism and amenity. While local communities like ours campaign to end this mindless destruction, no one in government has the guts to acknowledge or act on data that in the end will damn us all.

Shirley Saywell, Euroa Environment Group

Reckless refusal to take account of future fires

Ross Gittins highlights the determination of the state government to sacrifice high conservation-value forests in water catchments to appease vested interests. A worse example of environmental profligacy is its refusal to take account of the impacts of climate change and increasing bushfire risk in timber allocation orders.

After Black Saturday, when 13,500 hectares of ash forests died across the Central Highlands, the rate and intensity of logging in the unburnt ash forests continued undiminished. Even today, VicForests' timber supply outlook, advising government of how much forest is available for logging, takes no account of future fires.

Old growth ash forests in the Central Highlands now make up less than 2 per cent of the total ash forest area, with more than 40 per cent of its ash forests younger than 40 years. Forest biodiversity is fast disappearing and the continued unsustainable logging, given the certainty of future fires, is utterly reckless.

Jill Sanguinetti, Rubicon Forest Protection Group, Narbethong

Flushing the future for the grandkids

Another excellent "alarm bells should be ringing" article that highlights our lemming-like rush to the cliff of an unsustainable and overpopulated Melbourne. Stupid economic policy aside, is anybody else worried about the crisis of an assured (and affordable) water supply for their grandchildren in an increasingly dry and environmentally trashed Victoria?

Ross Bardin, Williamstown

Clear dereliction of duty by VicForests

Yes, Jo Wormald (Letters, 7/3), the "environmental travesty" of VicForests logging must end urgently; she has seen a part of what is happening from her home in Murrindindi. Also, we have new revealing environmental science from the Australian National University, and convincing economics from Ross Gittins. VicForests has, in effect, depleted Melbourne's water supply and wasted governmental funding for far too long. It's a scandal that must end now. Barbara Fraser, Burwood

urn:contentItem:5M2M-7D31-JD34-V4GF-00000-00More than 1000 hectares of pub...2016-11-01T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:38:12ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 8More than 1000 hectares of pub...

More than 1000 hectares of public land in central Victoria is about to be slashed in preparation for what experts are calling a high-risk fire season this summer.

Forest Fire Management Victoria will cut grass in Bendigo, Castlemaine, Maryborough, Echuca, Maldon, Eaglehawk and Heathcote this week.

Above-average rainfall in the region during 2016 has not only delayed maintenance work but has also encouraged vegetation growth that could prove dangerous as the weather warms.

FFMV regional director Paul Bates said privately-owned land was also at risk of bushfire and implored homeowners to regularly cut grass and clear their yards of leaves.

"Reducing bushfire risk is a shared responsibility," Mr Bates said.

"Reducing fuel loads on public land can only do so much - communities and households need to know how to be prepared and reduce their bushfire risk on their property."

The warnings follow a similar message from the Victorian emergency management commissioner, Craig Lapsley, last week.

Mr Lapsley told Fairfax Media residents in fire risk areas should start cleaning up their properties immediately.

"Do the work in late October/early November, but be prepared to revisit it to make sure you are ready for our summer," he said.

The fire risk is expected to be at its highest in January and February once fuel dries and temperatures rise.

Authorities are also reminding holidaymakers in parks and forests this long weekend to be vigilant about fire safety.

Forest staff will patrol the Cobaw Ranges until Tuesday, watching for unattended campfires and illegal firewood collection.

Fires should also be entirely extinguished with water, not soil, and all rubbish should be taken out of campsites, a FFMV spokesman said.

"While most people are doing the right thing, we want to remind people to keep safe when enjoying forest activities."

He also warned against off-road four-wheel driving and motorbiking.

People concerned about long grass in their neighbourhood, or who see suspicious behaviour on public land, should phone DELWP on 136 186.

urn:contentItem:4D9X-DY30-015G-V028-00000-00<published>2004-09-15T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:38:12Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>NEWS; Pg. 11</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Bushfire 'failure' denied</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>PAUL SELLARS</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">THE Victorian Government has again defended its record on land management in the wake of on-going claims it should be held liable for last year's bushfires.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Two groups formed after the fires assert poor public land management and an inept fire response by government agencies lay behind the fires' severity.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> The Stretton Group, which consists of fire and land management experts, is planning a class action in a bid to have key government agencies held responsible for the fire damage.</p><p>And a second group, Forest Fire Victoria, also claims "the enormous damage done to forest ecosystems, soils and water catchments was due to failed fire management programs".</p><p> The group claims "little or nothing had been done to reduce fuels by planned burning or any other means".</p><p> Its chairman is past chief fire officer of the former Department of Conservation, Forests and Lands, Athol Hodgson, who is also a member of the Stretton Group. Another former DCFL chief fire officer, Rod Incoll, is also a Forest Fire Victoria member.</p><p> The group describes last year's fires as "feral" and claims they behaved "in ways alien to the natural processes that forests require for their health, diversity and sustainability".</p><p> But a Department of Sustainability and Environment spokesman rejected the groups' assertions.</p><p> The spokesman also defended Emergency Services Commissioner Bruce Esplin's fire inquiry against claims by the Stretton Group it had been a failure.</p><p> He said as a result of the inquiry's recommendations, DSE had carried out reduction burns across 94,000 hectares this year -- double that of last year.</p><p> "(This) included community and asset-protection burns and burns that maintain and enhance the biodiversity values of forest and parks," he said.</p><p> The spokesman also dismissed the Stretton Group's claims that DSE was giving priority to asset protection burns at the expense of broader scale, "ecological" burns.</p><p> However, Forest Fire Victoria claims if current practices continue, "there will be further loss of biodiversity, more soils will become … eroded, more water catchments and storages will be degraded and resources for sustaining vital timber industries destroyed".</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:5VK3-R2J1-JBJ7-N4KJ-00000-00Teen whose family lost livelihood in bushfires in hospital after altercation with police2019-03-06T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:38:12ZLexisNexisTeen whose family lost livelihood in bushfires in hospital after altercation with policeSimone Fox Koob

Charlie Clarke, the son of Andrew Clarke, who owns Jinks Winery, was taken to Warragul hospital in a stable condition on Wednesday following a scuffle with a police officer.

The teenage son of a winery owner who lost his property in the Bunyip bushfires is in hospital after he was hurt during an altercation with a policeman.

Charlie Clarke, the son of Andrew Clarke, who owns Jinks Winery, was taken to Warragul hospital in a stable condition on Wednesday following a scuffle with a police officer on Tonimbuk Road about 4pm.

The Clarke family lost their livelihood following the destructive blaze, which ripped through thousands of hectares in just a few days and destroyed nine homes.

Police alleged on Wednesday that Charlie, 19, was "verbally aggressive" towards a senior constable while the officer was in a police car. When the member stepped out of the car, they allege the teen pushed the cop in the chest.

"The man was restrained and taken to the ground to prevent any further altercation," a spokesman said.

However, the teenager's father told 3AW Radio his son was grabbed by the neck and thrown to the ground by the policeman.

"He's a boy, he's 19, a willowy, six foot kid, not a muscle man, and a cop said something rude to him on Saturday and they had a bit of a confrontation," he said.

"[Today], Charlie was leaving with his cat to take it to the vet, because we found it today and all its paws were burnt off and everything. So we were taking it to the vet and he saw that same policeman again and he said, 'Can I get your name?' and started filming him with his camera.

"They had a kerfuffle," he said.

Mr Clarke also claimed the police officer grabbed his wife by the neck after she came over to intervene.

Charlie's sister Lucy told the radio station that the policeman was "pointing and screaming" at her as well.

"He grabbed my Mum around the neck after she was worried because he had thrown my brother's head into the ground. My brother has had concussion in the last two weeks," she said.

Charlie was spending the night at Warragul Hospital and was wearing a neck brace, the family said.

Police said in a statement that an ambulance was called as a precaution after they were told the man had an unrelated injury.

"The man was released pending summons in relation to assault police," the statement read.

An Ambulance Victoria spokesman confirmed a man was taken to Warragul Hospital in a stable condition.

The Clarke family were left heartbroken after they watched their property explode in flames on Sunday as bushfires burned through the Bunyip State Park.

"I saw our wine cellar door, restaurant and the house next to our Airbnb cottage explode on TV. That's how we found out," Andrew Clarke told The Age on Sunday.

"We've lost everything."

The devastated farmer fled his property late on Saturday with his wife and kids.

"We've lost our livelihood ... I planted that winery myself and put the first vines in back in 1979," he said.

He has also been vocal in recent days about the lack of back burning done in the area before the fire.

However, Forest Fire Management Victoria have said that conditions in recent months have not allowed them to go ahead with any planned back burns.

The Bunyip fire claimed nine homes with another two lost at Yinnar, in central Gippsland and 23 other buildings damaged or destroyed.

urn:contentItem:5VK5-CH41-JD34-V3G5-00000-00Bunyip fire attracts criticism2019-03-07T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:38:12ZLexisNexisNEWSBunyip fire attracts criticismPeter Kostos

Criticism of fire-fighting operations and the management of state and national parks has been levelled at authorities as a result of the Bunyip State Park fire.

The fire at Bunyip is one of many in Gippsland and up in the High Country that is still burning.

Labertouche North property owner Mark McGuffie, whose property abounds the Bunyip State Park, was one landholder critical of a "lack of management" of the park.

Mr McGuffie suffered property loss in the Black Saturday fires in February 2009 and had been critical of park management then.

He said nothing had changed since that time.

"I have 200 hectares of pasture, and a boundary with the State Park, kilometres in length," he said.

"In the 25 years I have owned the farm, the fire access track that runs the full length of my boundary has been blocked by fallen trees and purposefully-dug channels to stop vehicular access."

Mr McGuffie said he had the highest regard for the Country Fire Authority (CFA) volunteers, but not its hierarchy.

"There were six fire trucks just 2.5 kilometres away at a neighbour's property, but they were instructed not to attend my place," he said.

CFA chief officer Steve Warrington defended the authority and its volunteers.

"I make no apology for the strategic decisions that we make on the overall picture, particularly in relation to the safety of people - that includes community members, houses and firefighters," Mr Warrington said.

"We will make decisions not to send trucks into certain areas on the grounds of safety; trees can fall any time after a fire front has passed and we've already had one truck damaged.

"We will make decisions on asset protection, which can mean we've instructed crews to attack a fire from a certain position in more suitable conditions.

"Fire intensity can mean we hold water to attack in a more effective manner in a way that is safer for our crews."

Mr McGuffie said the only thing that saved his property on Sunday was a wind change and the Bunyip River.

He was angry with what he said was the continual ignorance of the state government and authorities.

But the Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning (DELWP) said more than 57 planned burns covering 2110 hectares had been conducted across the State in 2018-19.

DELWP senior media advisor Michael Pollock said mechanical treatments had also accounted for more than 5241 hectares of treatments for a total area treated of more than 7351ha.

Minister for Energy, Environment and Climate Change Lily D'Ambrosio said planned burns were a critical part of Victoria's bushfire management program, however were not something they relied on entirely.

"Public safety has to be our number one priority and we do not want to see a repeat of the Lancefield planned burn in 2015 where a badly planned burn in poor conditions led to disaster," Ms D'Ambrosio said.

"Where weather conditions make planned burning too dangerous, other fire mitigation strategies are used, such as fuel break slashing, track/culvert maintenance and removing obstacles and hazardous trees."

After advice from the Inspector General Emergency Management, Forest Fire Management Vic used a risk-reduction target to focus fuel management strategies on areas that would have the greatest impact.

A Government spokesperson said FFMVIC implemented a number of bushfire prevention measures in Bunyip State Park over the past 10 years, including planned burns in 2008, 2012 and 2016.

Recent opportunities for scheduled planned burns in the Bunyip area had been limited due to ongoing dry conditions.

Works carried out included about 45km of fuel break slashed in Bunyip State Park, including some earlier this year, and improvements to around 5km of dangerous roads through mulching vegetation and removed obstacles and hazardous trees.

The works also improved about 24km of tracks and two strategic fire access roads.

urn:contentItem:5M1S-BNF1-F0J6-J3XW-00000-00Wimmera prepares for fire season2016-10-28T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:38:12ZLexisNexisWimmera prepares for fire seasonSophie Boyd

AUSTRALIA is set to experience more extreme hot, dry and severe bushfire seasons according to the CSIRO and Bureau of Meteorology.

The latest State Of Climate report revealed much of Australia has experienced an increase in fire weather and longer fire seasons since the 1970s.

CSIRO senior scientist Helen Cleugh said the number of days per year over 35 degrees had increased in southern Australia.

"The changing climate significantly affects all Australians through increased heatwaves, more significant wet weather events and more severe fire weather conditions," she said.

"Some of the record-breaking extreme heat we have been seeing recently will be considered normal in 30 years' time."

The findings come as Wimmera emergency services prepare for a busy fire season.

In Lahuram last week, Country Fire Authority Steve Warrington said western Victoria, from Ballarat to the border, was the main area of concern in the state this fire season.

Forest Fire Management Victoria's Wimmera district manager Russell Manning said emergency services were prepared and working together ahead of the coming fire season, having just attended the Grampians fire conference to share information. Mr Manning said this season, January and February were likely to be the greatest risk period for public land fires, as well-watered vegetation dries out. He said the recent rain brought its own challenges.

"With lots of water it's fantastic for the Wimmera, the lakes fill up and it reinvigorates the community," he said. "What it also brings is a high number of people to use our lovely parks and reserves."

Mr Manning said the service was concerned the higher numbers of visitors would see a higher rate of non-compliant campfire use that could result in bushfires.

"It can happen very quickly, particularly if there's wind around," he said.

"People should never leave a fire unattended and should ensure they properly extinguish it when they leave."

urn:contentItem:5RRY-NY71-F0J6-J0CX-00000-00Toxic Legacy drags on2018-02-17T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:38:12ZLexisNexisSATURDAYPg. 11Toxic Legacy drags onVictoria Stone-Meadows

Attendees of a recent open house regarding inquiry into former Lands Department workers who were exposed to dangerous chemicals have been left frustrated.

The inquiry found employees were using more than double today's standard tolerable intake of the dangerous chemicals.

The inquiry resulted in free medical screening for former Lands Department workers.

However, former lands Department worker Barry Goldsmith said the open house left him with more questions than answers.

"I was hoping to find results of the inquiry but I don't think we are going to get answers for the blokes that are crook need the attention," Mr Goldsmith said.

"There are blokes on their last legs here today and they have been affected by the sprays and we just want a result one way or the other if the inquiry found the sprays affected us or doesn't affect us and we want a complete answer.

"To put it mildly it's been a balls up from day one."

The Courier revealed concerns surrounding the region's former Lands Department in September 2014.

The central finding in the report is that prior to 1981, it is plausible that exposure to a contaminant of 2,4,5-T called TCDD may cause non-Hodgkin lymphoma or soft sarcoma.

However, Mr Goldsmith said the government have not provided a definitive answer to if the spray used by the employees directly caused a great number of them to develop cancer and other illnesses.

Another former Lands Department employee, Don Humphrey, said not only have the meetings been ineffectual in keeping them informed on the progress of the inquiry but they have not been accessible to those living in Ballarat.

"We are here to do something to help the poor buggers who are in trouble and another thing is we want all these meetings and medicals done in Ballarat," he said.

"The last ones they had to go to Melbourne for and for a lot of these people it's just not possible, this is what we have to strive for.

"They know they are guilty but they don't want to say it."

DELWP's Forest, Fire and Regions Deputy Secretary Lee Miezis said they are implementing the recommendations from the inquiry.

"We know how important it is to deliver clarity for current and former Lands Department employees and their families," he said.

"These recommendations are not only a vital step towards delivering a higher standard in health and safety for past weed sprayers, but also an opportunity to embed best practice policies and procedures to benefit current workers."

urn:contentItem:5SB5-38D1-F031-X1DV-00000-00Country Fire Authority volunteer members locked out of Cann Valley station2018-05-14T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:38:12ZLexisNexisCountry Fire Authority volunteer members locked out of Cann Valley stationBy Amber Irving-Guthrie

Residents in a remote eastern Victoria community are concerned about their safety in the event of a fire because of an ongoing dispute involving their local fire brigade.

The Country Fire Authority in Cann River has locked the doors of the local brigade and changed the lock code after two members of the Cann Valley volunteer fire brigade were suspended, pending the completion of an investigation into disciplinary matters.

Other Cann Valley volunteers have gone on strike in support of the suspended members.

Suspended Cann River CFA member Sherylle Holster said the long-running dispute could put the community at risk.

"It means that [some] members cannot get into the station. Qualified members, certified members able to drive the tanker, cannot get into that station to take the tanker out," Ms Holster said.

"That obviously means that if there's a house fire in Cann River or the community that we protect, they can't get in to do the job."

Brigade culture questioned

Ms Holster is contesting her suspension, disputing the allegations made against her.

She said the CFA had accused her of attending an incident while on leave.

The Cann Valley brigade has struggled to attract enough members in recent years, which some volunteers say is because of the culture at the brigade.

The CFA is assuring Cann River residents that the dispute will not delay its response to any fires in the Cann Valley.

Cann River resident Bec Hopkins said she was worried about the safety of her town.

"I'm concerned that if there is a house fire or a grass fire on surrounding property, that it will cause a lot of alarm because we'll have to wait over 45 minutes for the CFA to come from Mallacoota or Bemm River," Ms Hopkins said.

Some Cann Valley members still have access to firefighting equipment and tankers.

Support arrangements in place, CFA says

CFA south east region assistant chief officer Trevor Owen said changing the lock code was standard practice following any CFA member's suspension.

"Service delivery levels remain unchanged, including the support arrangements with neighbouring CFA brigades," he said.

"Local firefighting resources from Forest Fire Management Victoria will also continue to respond in support of CFA to any fire in the Cann River community, as per existing procedures and practices."

Mr Owen said an operations officer with 30 years' experience would start work at Orbost next month, in a new position focused on repairing relationships within East Gippsland brigades.

"The two members were suspended pending the completion of an investigation into disciplinary matters," he said.

"It is important that this confidential process, as per any formal investigation, be adhered to, and therefore it would be inappropriate to comment on this matter until this process has run its course."

urn:contentItem:5GF7-T2M1-JDKC-R0JD-00000-00TASMANIA TO JOIN NATIONAL EFFORT TO HELP CANADA FIGHT HUNDREDS OF WILDFIRES THAT ARE BURNING IN COUNTRY'S WEST2015-07-11T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:38:12ZLexisNexisTASMANIA TO JOIN NATIONAL EFFORT TO HELP CANADA FIGHT HUNDREDS OF WILDFIRES THAT ARE BURNING IN COUNTRY'S WEST

Tasmania, Australia, July 11 -- Rene Hidding, Minister for Police and Emergency Management, issued the following media release:

Tasmania will join a national effort to help Canada fight the hundreds of wildfires that are burning in the country's west.

Four highly skilled firefighters - two from the Tasmania Fire Service and two from the Parks and Wildlife Service - will fly out on Monday as members of a 106-strong Australian firefighting contingent.

While Tasmanians are rugged up for winter, Canada is experiencing a dry, hot summer, which has resulted in numerous wildfires breaking out and burning across much of the country.

More than 13,000 people have been evacuated from their homes in northern Saskatchewan.

The escalating situation is overwhelming the capabilities of local firefighters, and the Canadian Interagency Forest Fire Centre requested help from Australia.

Not for the first time, Tasmania has joined other states in responding to the call, with four local firefighters to take their skills and experience to Canada.

Our firefighters will give local crews some much-needed respite, while also imparting their knowledge on tackling such severe wildfires.

We expect they will be working either in Edmonton, Alberta or Chilliwack, British Columbia and will be deployed for about six weeks. For any query with respect to this article or any other content requirement, please contact Editor at htsyndication@hindustantimes.com

urn:contentItem:5XM6-2TJ1-JBF5-T14C-00000-00Canberra smothered by smoke as two fires threaten to merge in NSW forest2019-11-29T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:38:12ZLexisNexisCanberra smothered by smoke as two fires threaten to merge in NSW forestNiki Burnside

Emergency call centres were overwhelmed with calls from concerned Canberrans late yesterday as smoke from a forest fire blanketed the city.

The North Black Range fire, burning in Tallaganda State Forest, was upgraded to a Watch and Act level about 4:00pm on Thursday but was later downgraded to Advice, where it remains.

The fire is about 40 kilometres away from Canberra, but a change in wind direction on Thursday night blew the strong-smelling smoke across the city.

More than 300 calls to triple-0 "consumed" the communications centre, triggering fire services to areas where no fires were burning, the ACT Emergency Services Agency Commissioner said.

This morning, Canberra residents were being urged to refer to the NSW Rural Fire Service website and use the Fires Near Me app for advice about fires in the area, in a bid to alleviate the strain on the service.

Smoke causes frenzy of calls from Canberra residents

A total fire ban has been declared in the ACT and surrounding NSW for today,with the fire danger level listed as "severe" and a top of 34 degrees Celsius expected.

Residents living outside Bungendore and Braidwood are being told to prepare as two fires burn towards each other in the Tallaganda State Forest.

The two blazes - the North Black Range fire, which covers 1,600 hectares, and the 60 hectare Palerang fire - are burning through a huge area in the forest.

About 7:30pm on Thursday, smoke from the fire blew towards Canberra when the wind changed direction, leading to widespread anxiety.

Many Canberrans, perhaps recalling the catastrophic 2003 bushfires that claimed both properties and lives, feared the worst.

But the advice from authorities was to keep calm, urging only people who see fire, and not smoke, to call in.

"I think it's a combination of concern form our community and also the fact that we've asked our community to remain vigilant throughout this fire season," ESA Commissioner Georgeina Whelan said.

"We're saying to our community they should not be alarmed - at this stage our territory is not under threat."

'Quite surreal': Farmers prepare to evacuate

Rural Fire Service district officer Darren Marks said this morning the fire was "fairly benign" and conditions had eased off for the time being.

But some properties outside Bungendore and Braidwood have prepared to evacuate as the fire burns close to boundaries.

"Those two fires are quite close together and given the forecast there is a good chance the two of those will merge," Mr Marks said.

"In these conditions the existing fires are going to be very hard to control and anybody who is in the area, particularly in Bombay, Little Bombay and Bendoura.

"I think it's fair to say that the bushfire danger season has well and truly appeared down in the local area."

Farmer Ellie Merriman, who lives about 10km outside Bungendore on the edge of the Tallaganda Forest, said she had been watching the fire burn on the other side of her boundary for days.

They had moved their livestock and were prepared to evacuate if the wind changed later in the day, she told the ABC.

"For the first time ever, I don't want the cool change to come through," she said.

"We're physically right next door to it, so where our property is it's just a hop and a skip away.

"Weirdly, it looks quite beautiful."

She urged anyone in a bushfire prone area to get ready early and know their emergency evacuation plan.

"We're organised, we've got our fire plan, we've tested all our plans ... we feel as prepared as we can be," she said.

"It just takes you so much longer that you think, moving horses, getting stuff together."

The family is now sleeping away from the property and returning during the day to monitor the situation.

"It's quite strange, very surreal, because we've been going through it for the past three days," he said.

'Don't go for a run': Smoke poses risk to chronically ill

Those with chronic conditions have been told to stay indoors and avoid any strenuous activities as the smoke lies across the Canberra region.

ACT Chief Health Officer Kerryn Coleman said a reduction in air quality had been registered and posed a risk to people with heart and lung conditions.

"We don't expect the majority of the community to have impacts, but those with chronic and existing heart and lung conditions may experience an exacerbation of their symptoms," she said.

"Some pregnant women may also be susceptible.

"We recommend these people limit their outdoor activities ... don't go for a run, don't do boot camp this morning."

Anyone who experiences a change in their symptoms should contact their GP or triple-0 if they are concerned about their health, she said.

"But we hope and don't expect to have a big jump in our numbers coming through."

urn:contentItem:5NWB-WCR1-JD3N-51CK-00000-00GLOBAL SNAPSHOT2017-06-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:38:12ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 12GLOBAL SNAPSHOT

Fire nears heritage site MADRID: A forest fire in southern Spain forced the evacuation of at least 1000 people and threatened a national park famous for its biodiversity and endangered species, authorities said yesterday. The fire started on Saturday night on Spain's southern coast, then advanced east to reach the Donana Nature Reserve, one of the country's most important wildlife sanctuaries and a UNESCO World Heritage site since 1994. The reserve protects over 107,000ha considered of extreme ecological value for their mix of ecosystems, including wetlands, dunes and woods.

Explosion toll rises LAHORE: The death toll from a tanker explosion in Pakistan has climbed to at least 153. Dozens more are in a critical condition, hospital and rescue officials said. The tragedy yesterday was sparked by an announcement over a mosque's loudspeaker that an overturned tanker truck had sprung a leak. Scores of villagers then raced to the scene with fuel containers to gather the oil. Then the wreck exploded, engulfing people in flames as they screamed in terror.

Pharmacy boss guilty BOSTON: The co-founder of a Massachusetts compounding pharmacy is set to be sentenced in a deadly nationwide meningitis outbreak that killed more than 60 people and sickened hundreds more. Barry Cadden was acquitted of second-degree murder charges under federal racketeering law, but convicted on conspiracy and fraud charges. Sentencing is scheduled for Monday in federal court in Boston.

Cadden was charged in connection with a 2012 fungal meningitis outbreak that was traced to contaminated injections of medical steroids made by the New England Compounding Centre in Framingham. Prosecutors say Cadden ran the centre in a dangerous way by skirting industry regulations on sterility in an effort to push production and make more money.

Disney map goes for $1mLOS ANGELES: The original colour map of Disneyland, used by Walt Disney to win funding for his first theme park, has been sold for almost $1 million. The 1953 artefact became the most lucrative Disneyland map when it went under the hammer for $US708,000 ($935,480) in Los Angeles yesterday, according to the auctioneers. It had been hidden away for more than 60 years after the cartoonist gave it to a production assistant Van Eaton Galleries co-owner Mike Eaton said: "After some pretty exciting bidding the map sold for $US708,000, making it the most expensive Disneyland map ever sold."

urn:contentItem:5JG1-V951-F0JP-W16H-00000-00Planned fire 'too big' for season2016-04-06T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:38:12ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 13Planned fire 'too big' for seasonBy KATH SULLIVAN

VOLUNTEER firefighters want the Government to call off a planned burn proposed for central Victoria.

A group of more than 35 CFA volunteers want to stop a 3000ha burn expected to take place in the Strathbogie Ranges this autumn.

CFA Volunteers for Forests aid "the burn is too big, the forest is too dry and the risk of damage is too great".

Group spokesman and Strathbogie farmer Andrew Townsend said the group - which included volunteers from Swanpool, Euroa, Violet Town and Ruffy - wanted to be involved in decisions about planned burns.

"We're not against prescribed burning, we're just saying please don't do this burn this year," said Mr Townsend, whose property adjoins the forest.

"Do it when the season changes.

"It would be on the cards that we'd be called to fight the fire (if it got out of control).

"We do not see any logic from a human safety perspective in burning these forests right now," Mr Townsend was also concerned a fire would drive kangaroos on to neighbouring properties and roads.

A Department of Environment Land Water and Planning spokesman said it had undertaken "considerable engage-ment" with the community regarding the Strathbogies burn.

He said the deputy secretary of its forest, fire and -regions group was to meet community members last night."We are listening to community concerns about planned burning," the spokesman said. "In response to concerns raised by the community, DELWP has agreed to conduct the burn in three stages, and we have also agreed to -involve the local stakeholder group in monitoring of the area before and after the burns."

urn:contentItem:5SWB-RXC1-JD34-V2PW-00000-00Europe burns as climate change fuels fire danger2018-07-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:38:12ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 14Europe burns as climate change fuels fire dangerENVIRONMENTNick Miller | London

As the official death toll from Greece's wildfires mounted, it became clear this was a national tragedy of a kind awfully familiar to Australians.

Horrific stories emerged as rescue workers made gruesome discoveries, such as the group of 26 men, women and children who perished while huddled together, trapped between the fire front and a sheer cliff. The death toll stood at 74 yesterday morning.

Many more survived by the skin of their teeth - fleeing into the sea as the fires overtook their holiday houses. It is the peak holiday period for locals and tourists. Fishing and coastguard vessels patrolled the coast, plucking people out of the water to safety.

Strong, unpredictable winds fanned and spread flames that killed people in their homes and in some of the hundreds, perhaps thousands, of cars that had tried to flee at the last minute but were lost in smoke and gridlock.

"Everything happened in seconds," Andreaas Passios, who lives in the devastated town of Mati, told the Times. "I grabbed a beach towel. It saved my life. I soaked it, grabbed my wife and we ran to the sea."

He and his wife stayed by the sea for two hours watching the inferno. "It was unbelievable. Gas canisters were exploding, burning pine cones were flying everywhere."

The fire is the latest, and most tragic, result of a heatwave that has baked Europe this summer, setting temperature records and starting fires from Norway to Spain. Sweden has lost an estimated 30,000 hectares of forest in wildfires across the country which were still burning on Tuesday - though the number of fires had dropped from 80 last week to around 20.

The area is more than double that damaged in the 2014 fire in Västmanland, which at the time was said to be Sweden's worst since the 19th century, The Local Sweden reported. It is more than 10 times the average annual area burnt by fire in a typical Swedish summer.

Forests are vital to the Swedish economy and the country has called for help fighting the fires. Summer temperatures typically hit the low 20s. This 30-plus heatwave is rare and authorities lack the resources for big fires.

A week ago, Italy sent two firefighting planes to help the Swedes, and other countries including Poland, Portugal and France also lent volunteers and equipment. The response is being coordinated by the European Union's Civil Protection and Emergency Response centre, which helps EU and neighbour countries share the load during disasters.

The same group has now mobilised to help Greece, while Australia has offered to help the recovery effort. Treasurer Scott Morrison said the government would provide whatever support was appropriate to help the fire-stricken areas.

"[We are] a country that is very familiar with the heartbreak and tragedy of fires," Mr Morrison said in Sydney yesterday.

"And as a country that also has one of the largest expatriate populations of Greek nationals of anywhere around the world, we deeply empathise with those who are caught up in these tragic fires in Greece. There will be many Australians I'm sure who have family members that may be affected."

Fires have also ravaged woods and grassland in northern Finland near the Russian border, Latvia has lost more than 800 hectares in fires that have raged for almost a week, and a Norwegian firefighter died last week trying to contain a wildfire.

Last year, 66 people died from wildfires in Portugal - its biggest loss of lives.

Also last year, an EU-commissioned report predicted new "forest fire danger extremes" due to climate change in Europe.

Scientific modelling has shown the south and south-eastern parts of Europe would be worst hit. And these trends would continue to get worse - and extend northwards.

About a third of Europe - 215 million hectares - is covered by forest. In 2010, wildfires damaged about half a million hectares but this number is expected to rise dramatically. Last year, the burnt area in Portugal, Spain and Italy alone was almost double that.

The report from the EU's science service, the Joint Research Centre, found that climate change would reduce the protective effect of the Alps, which creates an area of high moisture guarding Europe's heart.

Down by the sea, lower rainfall and higher temperatures would dry forests into summer tinderboxes.

"It is clear that the danger of forest fires driven by weather increases with climate change around the Mediterranean," the report found.

The report had expected relatively little change in weather-driven fire danger across northern Europe due to climate change. Another report from the European Environment Agency said Mediterranean countries were already seeing more heat extremes, reduced rainfall and river flows, and resulting severe droughts, lower crop yields, forest fires and heatwave deaths.

In the north of the continent, the temperature rise will be even bigger than the global average, with a decrease in snow and ice cover, an increase in crop yields and decrease in heating costs, but increasing risk of damage from winter storms.

In central and eastern Europe there will be less summer rain and a bigger risk of forest fires. In the mountains there will be less skiing and more species extinction.

"[These heatwaves are] exactly the kind of event we are expecting to see," said Professor Corinne Le Quere, director of the climate change research team at the University of East Anglia.

"In a warmer climate we expect more extreme events, we expect extreme heatwaves to be hotter and last longer."

However fire is "a whole different beast" and harder to predict, she said. Wildfires have a range of causes and only some are linked to climate change: for example heat drying out forests, and more lightning starting fires.

Some wildfires, such as those two years ago in Canada, have been closely examined and the attribution to climate change is "very clear", Professor Le Quere said.

She expects scientists to closely examine the fires in Sweden this year, to see if there can be an attribution to climate change. If so, this may confound models that had predicted no increase in fires due to a predicted increase in rainfall.

Professor Le Quere said it was clear that global warming would continue as long as carbon emissions were not brought under control, leading to more and more extreme hot weather.

"We really need to think about how do we tackle climate change in a way that protects us and reduces risk," she said.

Research estimated that without mitigation and adaptation there would be 200,000 heat-related deaths per year in Europe by 2100, as well as (EURO)10 billion ($15.7 billion) worth of river flood damages, increased forest fire damage and reduced crop yields.

However there are already EU-wide adaptation strategies in place, ranging from dykes and flood drains to ambitious long-term goals on reducing greenhouse gas emissions by 40 per cent by 2030 and by 80-95 per cent by 2050. The EU is behind about 10 per cent of global greenhouse gas emissions.

The reduction can be achieved through effective carbon prices and regulation and through investment in renewable energy and energy efficiency, the EEA said.

urn:contentItem:5GY9-C2X1-JC0X-K2NJ-00000-00US:Five dead in California wildfires2015-09-18T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:38:12ZLexisNexisINTERNATIONAL NEWSUS:Five dead in California wildfires

  US WILDFIRES
   LOS ANGELES, Sept 17 DPA - California authorities have recovered the bodies of four more people killed in wildfires raging in the central part of the state, bringing the death toll to five.


   The remains of four men who died separately in the Valley fire, north of San Francisco, and the Butte fire, south-east of the capital Sacramento, were discovered on Wednesday, officials in Lake and Calaveras counties told news media.
   A 72-year-old disabled woman was killed as she tried to flee the Valley fire on Saturday.
   Hundreds of people have been left homeless by the two fires, which have together destroyed more than 800 homes and burned more than 582 square kilometres of land in a little more than a week.
   The cause of both fires is under investigation.
   The electricity utility told local media one of its power lines may have sparked the Butte fire September 9.
   Firefighters made some headway in fighting the fires on Thursday, helped by rain and cooling temperatures.
   The Butte fire was 49 per cent contained, and the Valley fire was 35 per cent contained, state fire agency Cal Fire said.
   A forest fire that threatened some of the world's oldest and largest trees in California's Sequoia National Park was two-thirds contained, the federal National Wildfire Co-ordinating Group said.
   The so-called Rough fire has burned more than 570 square kilometres, among the largest fires ever in the state, according to Cal Fire.
   DPA aro

urn:contentItem:5TC2-4PK1-JD34-V2BV-00000-00Fire authorities call on people to prepare for summer now | News Focus2018-09-28T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:38:12ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 4Fire authorities call on people to prepare for summer now | News FocusPRU SAIMOUN

RELATED: Fire prevention preparation well underway across the Wimmera

RELATED: Fire fight is constant - just different - for Horsham urban firefighters

This year's fire danger period could start up to a month earlier than usual.

The Country Fire Authority's District 17 operations manager Craig Brittain says due to the ongoing dry weather, officials were preparing for an early and difficult season.

The consultative phase with group officers, Forest Fire Management Victoria and municipal fire officers was still in process looking at a variety of factors such as soil moisture, fuel load and weather forecasts, before a date was set, he said.

Farmer and Grampians Group officer, Robert Kelm, agreed that the Wimmera was facing "one of those years" this fire season.

Mr Kelm, who lives at Green Lake, said because it was so dry, any fire that started this season would burn very fast.

Mr Kelm and Mr Brittain urged everyone to tidy up their properties now before it got too late, and to be ready for what was shaping up to be a potentially volatile season across the region.

With below average rain for the past months, away from channels and lakes, it was very dry; even some of the trees had no moisture in them.

Mr Kelm said lightning strikes could be a problem in the dry bush.

He welcomed a code of practice for harvesting recently put in place so that on "real dirty days" the word was put out to stop harvesting until the risk of sparking a fire was lower.

"It's been working really well. We only had one header fire in the area last season," Mr Kelm said.

Mr Brittain said that this season, for the first time, the fire authority would introduce a zero tolerance for illegal fires.

The fire authority will work in co-operation with police and other organisations.

Mr Brittain said illegal fires were defined as any fire that was lit or allowed to remain alight, unless within the prescription of a permit.

This could include an accidental spark from a grinder or welder that started a fire, campfires not properly extinguished or burn-offs that got away.

Any illegal fire - particularly on a Total Fire Ban Day - could attract a charge and penalties up to $36,400 or two years in jail.

Mr Brittain said every year had a summer period, so every year there were high risk periods and people needed to be aware of those risks.

He said he had been speaking on the radio about three weeks ago, urging people to start cleaning up blocks and preparing because it was going to be an early season.

"We know it will be early, hotter, longer and drier and the community needs to take that on board. Mitigate all risks or take the consequences," he said.

Mr Brittain said if anyone has any doubts about what they could or couldn't do around cleaning up, or preparing for fires, they could visit a CFA office or go to the website www.cfa.vic.gov.au and check the 'Can I or Can't I?' brochure.â€‹

urn:contentItem:5NTV-F641-F0J6-J2B4-00000-00Eucalypts blamed as nation mourns blaze deaths2017-06-20T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:38:12ZLexisNexisWORLDPg. 12Eucalypts blamed as nation mourns blaze deathsPortugal Joao Lima Lisbon

Portugal has declared three days of national mourning after a forest fire triggered by thunderstorms in the north of the country killed more than 60 people, many of them fleeing in their cars.

At least 30 people died in vehicles, with more bodies found near cars on the side of a road and others in rural areas near Pedrogao Grande, Secretary of State for Internal Administration Jorge Gomes said on Sunday.

More than 350 soldiers and 700 firefighters are still working to contain the blaze, which erupted on Saturday and spread amid temperatures that approached 40 degrees. Smoke has hampered airborne efforts, Mr Gomes said.

Portuguese President Marcelo Rebelo de Sousa went to the scene, about 175 kilometres north-east of Lisbon, after midnight.

Police said lightning striking a tree probably caused the fire. Minister of Internal Administration Constanca Urbano de Sousa, also in Pedrogao, said that "when this ends" an assessment will be made about what happened.

"It's the greatest tragedy of human lives that we've seen with forest fires in Portugal in the last few years," Prime Minister Antonio Costa said in comments broadcast by television channel SIC Noticias. There were 156 fires on Saturday, he said.

Joao Branco, president of Quercus, an environmental association, said that the fires reflected "a situation of negligence" and a flawed approach to forestry that has led to the large-scale replacement of pine trees with eucalypts in areas around Pedrogao Grande.

Mr Branco said the government had regularly promised to improve Portugal's forestry policies, but that instead, "everything continued in the same way".

The Portuguese branch of the World Wildlife Fund said the devastating fires should serve as another urgent reminder that the government needed to improve its forestry management.

"Responsible forestry management is more effective and financially more efficient than the huge mechanisms used every year to combat forest fires," WWFPortugal said.

At least four other significant wildfires affected different areas of the country on Sunday but the one in Pedrogao Grande was responsible for all the deaths.

Firefighting aircraft were being sent from France and Spain, the EU's humanitarian aid commissioner Christos Stylianides said.

Mr Gomes urged people to stay away from the scene.

AAP, Reuters, agencies

urn:contentItem:5RJD-DSB1-F0J6-J3GS-00000-00Thinking man wins gong2018-01-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:38:12ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 7Thinking man wins gongDerrick Krusche

Ballarat fire expert Gary Morgan, the man responsible for bringing the first orange air crane to Australia, says serious bushfires will never be stopped by aircraft alone.

The longtime Alfredton resident - who today will be made a member of the general division of the order of Australia (AM) - has called on government to invest more money into planned burning, maintaining fire access roads and protecting biodiversity before big blazes break out.

His message comes after a string of big grassfires across the Ballarat region in recent weeks, including at Mount Misery on January 19 when a fleet of 12 aircraft were called in.

Mr Morgan, who was chief fire officer of what is now DELWP when he inspected an air crane in Canada in the 1990s, said Victoria needed to invest more in land management as the state was one of the most fire prone regions in the world.

"We know we've got a climate where you get low humidity, high temperatures and very strong winds and nothing will stop those big fires - not even these huge air tankers," he said.

"If all we focus on is putting out fires, then we're going to spend more and more money every year.

"We're going to have bigger and bigger air tankers and we're going to have more destruction, more lives lost.

"But we need to turn that around, we need to get the land to the state where we'll be able to have fires and not have that detrimental effect."

When most Victorians think of bushfires they think of CFA crews fighting them, or "red stuff on the red stuff", but the work DELWP does through managing land helps prevent emergencies before they make media headlines.

Mr Morgan now chairs the Forest Fire Management Committee at the Institute of Foresters of Australia.

He was awarded today as a nod to his service to the community through emergency response organisations and his research into forest and fire management.

"Not often people in land management get such recognition, so I see it as part of all the good people who worked with me over a long time, both landholders on private land and on public land," he said.

But Mr Morgan's career has not been without its dark moments as fire can be deadly.

"You see people who die," he said.

"In 2003, three people were washed into the Buckland River while trying to retrieve a tanker which had break failure in the Alpine Fires. I knew two of them and knew the father of the third.

"It becomes personal, I was chief fire officer at the time.

"It's always personal. Whenever you're sending firefighters to a fire, there is always a risk."

urn:contentItem:5TC2-4PK1-JD34-V2RN-00000-00Fire authorities call on people to prepare for summer now | News Focus2018-09-28T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:38:12ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 4Fire authorities call on people to prepare for summer now | News FocusPRU SAIMOUN

RELATED: Fire prevention preparation well underway across the Wimmera

RELATED: Fire fight is constant - just different - for Horsham urban firefighters

This year's fire danger period could start up to a month earlier than usual.

The Country Fire Authority's District 17 operations manager Craig Brittain says due to the ongoing dry weather, officials were preparing for an early and difficult season.

The consultative phase with group officers, Forest Fire Management Victoria and municipal fire officers was still in process looking at a variety of factors such as soil moisture, fuel load and weather forecasts, before a date was set, he said.

Farmer and Grampians Group officer, Robert Kelm, agreed that the Wimmera was facing "one of those years" this fire season.

Mr Kelm, who lives at Green Lake, said because it was so dry, any fire that started this season would burn very fast.

Mr Kelm and Mr Brittain urged everyone to tidy up their properties now before it got too late, and to be ready for what was shaping up to be a potentially volatile season across the region.

With below average rain for the past months, away from channels and lakes, it was very dry; even some of the trees had no moisture in them.

Mr Kelm said lightning strikes could be a problem in the dry bush.

He welcomed a code of practice for harvesting recently put in place so that on "real dirty days" the word was put out to stop harvesting until the risk of sparking a fire was lower.

"It's been working really well. We only had one header fire in the area last season," Mr Kelm said.

Mr Brittain said that this season, for the first time, the fire authority would introduce a zero tolerance for illegal fires.

The fire authority will work in co-operation with police and other organisations.

Mr Brittain said illegal fires were defined as any fire that was lit or allowed to remain alight, unless within the prescription of a permit.

This could include an accidental spark from a grinder or welder that started a fire, campfires not properly extinguished or burn-offs that got away.

Any illegal fire - particularly on a Total Fire Ban Day - could attract a charge and penalties up to $36,400 or two years in jail.

Mr Brittain said every year had a summer period, so every year there were high risk periods and people needed to be aware of those risks.

He said he had been speaking on the radio about three weeks ago, urging people to start cleaning up blocks and preparing because it was going to be an early season.

"We know it will be early, hotter, longer and drier and the community needs to take that on board. Mitigate all risks or take the consequences," he said.

Mr Brittain said if anyone has any doubts about what they could or couldn't do around cleaning up, or preparing for fires, they could visit a CFA office or go to the website www.cfa.vic.gov.au and check the 'Can I or Can't I?' brochure.â€‹

urn:contentItem:5MV5-9051-F0J6-J4YD-00000-00Warm weather a sign of things to come2017-02-10T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:38:12ZLexisNexisWarm weather a sign of things to come

AS the heatwave affecting most of the country swept through South Australia, the West Coast sweltered through its hottest day in two years.

Ceduna recorded a maximum temperature of 46.1 degrees on Wednesday, the hottest day since February 14, 2015 and just short of the record maximum of 47.9 degrees back in January 1990.

Wudinna reached a top of 44.6 degrees.

There were rolling blackouts in parts of the state, although Eyre Peninsula towns were spared on this occasion.

The warm weather has continued today, although it did not reach the forecast maximum of 35 degrees, and is expected to carry through to Friday and Saturday with a high of 36 degrees both days, before cooler weather arrives on Sunday.

The hot conditions throughout Eyre Peninsula coincided with a report warning Australians to expect more extreme weather events as climate change worsens.

According to the Climate Council of Australia report released this week, Cranking Up the Intensity: Climate Change and Extreme Weather Events, Australia is experiencing hotter and longer heatwaves with increased bushfire risk as fire seasons are lasting longer.

It said the Forest Fire Danger Index may increase across southern Australia, including coastal regions by seven per cent by 2030 and by 30 per cent by 2090 under a high emissions scenario.

As well as hot conditions the report has linked climate change to extreme storm events, including the storm that affected South Australia in September last year, which took out power across the state, including on the West Coast.

It states the oceans are warming, especially at the surface, which is driving higher evaporation rates and the warmer atmosphere can hold more water vapour.

The report said the 1 per cent increase in global temperatures, together with increasing evaporation had lead to a 7 per cent increase in water vapour in the atmosphere.

The report said the burning of fossil fuels was linked to the temperature rises with Australia set to miss its target of a 26 to 28 per cent reduction in emissions by the year 2030.
